speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: SCENE XI. Alexandria. CLEOPATRA's palace.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Enter MARK ANTONY with Attendants

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Hark! the land bids me tread no more upon't;

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: It is ashamed to bear me! Friends, come hither:

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: I am so lated in the world, that I

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Have lost my way for ever: I have a ship

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Laden with gold; take that, divide it; fly,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: And make your peace with Caesar.

speaker: All
text_entry: Fly! not we.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: I have fled myself; and have instructed cowards

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: To run and show their shoulders. Friends, be gone;

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: I have myself resolved upon a course

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Which has no need of you; be gone:

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: My treasure's in the harbour, take it. O,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: I follow'd that I blush to look upon:

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: My very hairs do mutiny; for the white

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Reprove the brown for rashness, and they them

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: For fear and doting. Friends, be gone: you shall

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Have letters from me to some friends that will

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Sweep your way for you. Pray you, look not sad,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Nor make replies of loathness: take the hint

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Which my despair proclaims; let that be left

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Which leaves itself: to the sea-side straightway:

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: I will possess you of that ship and treasure.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Leave me, I pray, a little: pray you now:

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Nay, do so; for, indeed, I have lost command,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Therefore I pray you: I'll see you by and by.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Sits down

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Enter CLEOPATRA led by CHARMIAN and IRAS; EROS following

speaker: EROS
text_entry: Nay, gentle madam, to him, comfort him.

speaker: IRAS
text_entry: Do, most dear queen.

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: Do! why: what else?

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Let me sit down. O Juno!

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: No, no, no, no, no.

speaker: EROS
text_entry: See you here, sir?

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: O fie, fie, fie!

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: Madam!

speaker: IRAS
text_entry: Madam, O good empress!

speaker: EROS
text_entry: Sir, sir,--

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Yes, my lord, yes; he at Philippi kept

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: His sword e'en like a dancer; while I struck

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: The lean and wrinkled Cassius; and 'twas I

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: That the mad Brutus ended: he alone

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Dealt on lieutenantry, and no practise had

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: In the brave squares of war: yet now--No matter.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Ah, stand by.

speaker: EROS
text_entry: The queen, my lord, the queen.

speaker: IRAS
text_entry: Go to him, madam, speak to him:

speaker: IRAS
text_entry: He is unqualitied with very shame.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Well then, sustain him: O!

speaker: EROS
text_entry: Most noble sir, arise; the queen approaches:

speaker: EROS
text_entry: Her head's declined, and death will seize her, but

speaker: EROS
text_entry: Your comfort makes the rescue.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: I have offended reputation,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: A most unnoble swerving.

speaker: EROS
text_entry: Sir, the queen.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: O, whither hast thou led me, Egypt? See,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: How I convey my shame out of thine eyes

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: By looking back what I have left behind

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: 'Stroy'd in dishonour.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: O my lord, my lord,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Forgive my fearful sails! I little thought

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: You would have follow'd.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Egypt, thou knew'st too well

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: My heart was to thy rudder tied by the strings,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: And thou shouldst tow me after: o'er my spirit

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Thy full supremacy thou knew'st, and that

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Thy beck might from the bidding of the gods

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Command me.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: O, my pardon!

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Now I must

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: To the young man send humble treaties, dodge

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: And palter in the shifts of lowness; who

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: With half the bulk o' the world play'd as I pleased,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Making and marring fortunes. You did know

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: How much you were my conqueror; and that

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: My sword, made weak by my affection, would

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Obey it on all cause.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Pardon, pardon!

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Fall not a tear, I say; one of them rates

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: All that is won and lost: give me a kiss;

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Even this repays me. We sent our schoolmaster;

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Is he come back? Love, I am full of lead.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Some wine, within there, and our viands! Fortune knows

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: We scorn her most when most she offers blows.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Exeunt
